qas.question: In what year did Missouri pass a law stating that executions should be inside of or near a jail?
What procedure did Missouri use to execute prisoners in 1919?
In the Missouri of 1919, who handed out passes to witness executions?
In approximately what year did a movement in favor of private executions begin in the US?
In what year did Missouri pass a law stating that executions should be outside of a jail?
What procedure did Missouri use to free prisoners in 1919?
In the Missouri of 1959, who handed out passes to witness executions?
In approximately what year did a movement in favor of public executions begin in the US?

context: Around <a3_0><b7_0>1890<b7_0/><a3_0/>, a political movement developed in the United States to mandate private executions. Several states enacted laws which required executions to be conducted within a "wall" or "enclosure" to "exclude public view." For example, in <a0_0><b4_0>1919<b4_0/><a0_0/>, the Missouri legislature adopted a statute (L.1919, p. 781) which required, "the sentence of death should be executed within the county jail, if convenient, and otherwise within an enclosure near the jail." The Missouri law permitted <a2_0>the <b6_0>local sheriff<b6_0/><a2_0/> to distribute passes to individuals (usually local citizens) whom he believed should witness the <a1_0><b5_0>hanging<b5_0/><a1_0/>, but the sheriffs – for various reasons – sometimes denied passes to individuals who wanted to watch. Missouri executions conducted after 1919 were not "public" because they were conducted behind closed walls, and the general public was not permitted to attend.
